awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Anticipating Risks and Benefits of Precision Agriculture (PA) or the Future of Agricultural Work and Workforce: A Multi-Stakeholder Research Agenda
awd_abstract_narration:
Precision agriculture comprises a collection of data-based agricultural technologies and practices that use localized farm data, at the appropriate time and location to make better farming decisions. Technological transformations, such as precision agriculture can improve economic productivity and environmental sustainability but can be disruptive to the future of agricultural work and the workforce. Some agricultural jobs will be lost since the tasks can be more efficiently performed by machines and algorithms. However, many jobs will flourish and augment worker productivity and quality of life. The overall goal of this planning grant is to comprehensively examine the risks and benefits of precision agriculture technologies to the farm or operation-level workforce in the near future (10-15 years). Workforce examined in this project will include self-employed farmers, farm and livestock operators, hired farm workers and agriculture support professionals in South Dakota and Vermont. Planning discussions with stakeholders from the industry, government, academia, workers and non-profit non-farm organizations will help to create understanding and appreciation for an inclusive and responsible approach to workforce and technology development initiatives. The longer-term benefits of this project include prioritizing, designing, and updating precision agriculture technologies and workforce development initiatives that can potentially reduce risks (and augment benefits) for agricultural workforce.

The long-term intellectual merit of this project includes (1) identifying and strategically linking multi-sectoral stakeholders to enhance understanding of the science of work and workforce development (e.g. how people learn new skills or augment skills to new work roles and contexts); (2) help evolve new areas of precision agriculture technology research (e.g. system designs that focus on data privacy, trust, and accessibility), and (3) foster development and modifications of participatory stakeholder approaches (e.g. foresight methods applied to envision desirable futures of agricultural work) and complex system tools (e.g. network analysis and topic modelling). The project will convene focus group discussions to interrogate numerous future implications of PA on the agricultural workforce and explore risks and benefits from several lenses, including technological, social, ethical, and governance. Focus group data will be analyzed through topic modeling and network analysis to identify new and existing multi-sectoral network connections based on actors and organizations' common interests, concerns, and visions of agricultural workforce requirements. This project and the subsequent NSF Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier research grant will build on the successful precision agriculture research initiatives at South Dakota State University and transdisciplinary research in Complex Systems at the University of Vermont to advance new workforce development approaches and precision agriculture technologies for the purpose of preparing future workforce under precision agriculture. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop the necessary research personnel, research infrastructure, and foundational work to expand the opportunities for studying future technology, future workers, and future work at the level of a FW-HTF full research proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

Precision agriculture is a farm management approach that employs data-based agricultural technologies and practices to generate site-specific farm recommendations. Despite potential economic and environmental benefits, adoption or use of precision agriculture among farmers and farm workers has remained low. This project intended to examine the social and ethical risks and benefits of precision agriculture technologies for farmers and farm workers. We chose two sites for research: South Dakota and Vermont. The state of Vermont has more small-scale, organic and dairy farms compared to South Dakota, which tends to focus on corn and soybeans on large farms. These different locations gave us a good mix of agricultural systems and farm labor to investigate how precision agriculture will impact the future of farm work and workers.

Methods

In Fall 2019, the project team conducted six focus group discussions and foresight (visioning) exercises in South Dakota and Vermont with precision agriculture software and hardware developers; state and field extension specialists; non-profit/government agencies; and crop, livestock, and dairy farmers. Participants deliberated on the risks and benefits of artificial intelligence-based systems for farming decisions, education and training needs to prepare current and future precision agriculture workforce, and how precision agriculture will impact rural communities and farms of different sizes. Graduate and undergraduate students were advised by the senior project personnel to analyze data from these workshops using qualitative (thematic coding) and quantitative (network analysis) methods.

Research Outcomes

Research outcomes are summarized and presented in Figure 1 and 2. The network diagram (Figure 1) shows that improving trust and confidence in Artificial Intelligence-based recommendations was a main priority identified by several different clusters of participants. This theme was prevalent among participants in Vermont and South Dakota, it cuts across most sectors, and is both a key concern and opportunity as we move forward in developing integrated decision-support systems and understanding how to train future farm workers. Other priorities elucidated from this analysis include reskilling farm labor, more strongly emphasized by the industry; re-investing in Extension to aid in the adoption of precision agriculture, and using precision agriculture to improve crop yield, soil, and water quality. Results from the thematic coding analysis (Figure 2) provide nuanced explanation of the topics generated from topic modeling and network analysis. For example, participants agreed that managing this transition in farm work requires: (1) integrating technologies (e.g. remote sensing, nanotechnology, and big data algorithms) into tools and knowledge to help farmers overcome production, environmental and social barriers (e.g. trust in artificial intelligent systems); (2) achieving on-farm sustainability with workforce augmentation (e.g. the use of in-situ sensors to monitor nutrient pollution), and (3) optimizing farm -level workers? quality of life through designing of workforce development and policy initiatives. Findings from this planning grant was used to develop a subsequent and successful large research proposal under the NSF Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier program.

Education Outcomes

A Sociology PhD student at South Dakota State University was funded for one calendar year through this grant. The student used the project results to inform their dissertation research. A first-year undergraduate student in Sociology at South Dakota State University was provided a Summer stipend to intern with the principal investigator. This internship provided the student training on the tools and methods used in social sciences for anticipating risks and benefits of emerging agricultural technologies. A Masters student at University of Vermont in Community Development and Applied Economics presented findings from this research project to the international annual meeting of Earth System Governance.

Broader Impacts

This planning grant was an incubator of novel ideas and formation of an interdisciplinary network of people that are engaged in the broad fields of precision agriculture, rural revitalization, and design ethics, in South Dakota and Vermont. This planning grant elicited the necessary social conditions needed to prioritize, design, and update precision agriculture technologies and workforce development initiatives that can potentially reduce risks and augment benefits for agricultural workers. Such participatory design of technology can create new and meaningful forms of farm work for both small and large farms that can help achieve goals of socioeconomic and environmental sustainability. Overall findings from the project can help technology developers and government agencies in the precision agriculture space reflect on the social and ethical implications of their innovations and policy decisions.
